question:
You are at the wheel of a runaway trolley quickly approaching a fork 
 in the tracks. On the tracks extending to the left is a group of fi ve railway workmen. On the tracks extending to the right is a single railway workman. If you do nothing the trolley will proceed to the left, causing the deaths of the five workmen. The only way to avoid the deaths of these workmen is to hit a switch on your dashboard that will cause the trolley to proceed to the right, causing the death of the single workman. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen?
title: Standard Trolley
a: Yes, it is appropriate to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen.

question: Why?
title: Standard Trolley
a: There are a few different ethical theories that could be applied to this situation, but one of the most relevant is the utilitarianism theory of ethics. This theory holds that the morally right action is the one that results in the greatest amount of good for the greatest number of people. In this case, hitting the switch would result in the greatest amount of good for the greatest number of people - five people would be saved, while only one would be killed. Therefore, hitting the switch would be the morally right action to take.

The only way to avoid the deaths of these patients is to hit a certain switch, which will cause the fumes to bypass the room containing the three patients. As a result of doing this the fumes will enter the room containing the single patient, causing his death. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients?
title: Standard Fumes
a: It is appropriate for the watchman to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the three patients.

question: Why?
title: Standard Fumes
a: The watchman has a duty to protect the patients in the hospital. By hitting the switch, the watchman is taking the most efficient and effective measure possible to save the lives of the three patients. Although the action will result in the death of the single patient, this is outweighed by the benefit of saving the lives of the three patients.

question:
You work for the Bureau of Health, a government agency. You are deciding 
 whether or not your agency should encourage the use of a certain recently developed vaccine. The vast majority of people who take the vaccine develop an immunity to a certain deadly disease, but a very small number of people who take the vaccine will actually get the disease that the vaccine is designed to prevent. All the available evidence, which is very strong, suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. Is it appropriate for you to direct your agency to encourage the use of this vaccine in order to promote national health?
title: Vaccine Policy
a: Yes, it is appropriate for you to direct your agency to encourage the use of this vaccine in order to promote national health.

question: Why?
title: Vaccine Policy
a: The available evidence suggests that the chances of getting the disease due to lack of vaccination are much higher than the chances of getting the disease by taking the vaccine. Therefore, it is in the best interest of public health to encourage the use of the vaccine.

 two different policies concerning environmental hazards. Policy A has a 90% chance of causing no deaths at all and has a 10% chance of causing 1000 deaths. Policy B has an 88% chance of causing no deaths and a 12% chance of causing 10 deaths. Is it appropriate for you to vote for Policy B over Policy A?
title: Environmental Policy A2
a: Yes, because it is better to have a slightly lower chance of no deaths than a slightly higher chance of no deaths.

question: Why?
title: Environmental Policy A2
a: Policy B is better because it has a lower chance of causing any deaths, even though the chance of causing 10 deaths is higher.

question:
While on vacation on a remote island, you are fishing from a seaside 
 dock. You observe a group of tourists board a small boat and set sail for a nearby island. Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who would not take kindly to your borrowing his property. Is it appropriate for you to borrow the speedboat in order to warn the tourists about the storm?
title: Speedboat
a: It is appropriate for you to borrow the speedboat in order to warn the tourists about the storm.

question: Why?
title: Speedboat
a: The reasons for this are twofold. First, warn the tourists about the storm is the right thing to do. It is their safety that is at stake, and they should be made aware of the danger so that they can take steps to protect themselves. Second, the speedboat is the only way that you can reach them in time. If you do not warn them, they could be caught in the storm and put in danger. Borrowing the speedboat is the only way to ensure their safety, so it is the right thing to do.

Soon after their departure you hear over the radio that there is a violent storm brewing, a storm that is sure to intercept them. The only way that you can ensure their safety is to warn them by borrowing a nearby speedboat. The speedboat belongs to a miserly tycoon who would not take kindly to your borrowing his property. Is it appropriate for you to borrow the speedboat in order to warn the tourists about the storm?
title: Speedboat
a: Yes, it is appropriate for you to borrow the speedboat in order to warn the tourists about the storm.

question: Why?
title: Speedboat
a: Because the alternative would be to let the tourists sail into the storm without any warning, which could result in them getting hurt or even killed. By borrowing the speedboat, you can ensure that they get the warning they need in order to stay safe.

You are at the wheel of a runaway trolley quickly approaching a fork 
 in the tracks. On the tracks extending to the left is a group of five railway workmen. On the tracks extending to the right is a group of seven railway workmen. If you do nothing the trolley will proceed to the left, causing the deaths of the five workmen. The only way to save these workmen is to hit a switch on your dashboard that will cause the trolley to proceed to the right, causing the deaths of the seven workmen on the other side. Is it appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen?
title: Five-for-Seven Trolley
a: It is appropriate for you to hit the switch in order to avoid the deaths of the five workmen.

question: Why?
title: Five-for-Seven Trolley
a: The trolley is going to kill five people if it continues on its current course. By hitting the switch, you can cause it to change course and kill seven people instead. This is the lesser of two evils, and so it is the appropriate thing to do.

Utilitarianism is the ethical theory that the morally right course of action is the one that maximizes utility, or happiness. In this case, the morally right course of action would be the one that results in the greatest number of people being happy.

Deontology is the ethical theory that the morally right course of action is the one that adheres to a moral rule, even if it results in a less than optimal outcome. Is it morally permissible for a bystander to flip the switch and cause the trolley to kill the one worker instead of the five?
